description: From Middle English nicetee, from Old French niceté (“simpleness, foolishness”), from nice (“simple, foolish”); equivalent to nice +‎ -ty.

examples: We met the new captain while we were taking enemy fire and were unable to observe the niceties of formal introductions.

entries.meaning: Subtlety or precision of use; exactness; preciseness.
examples: A rocket-propelled grenade doesn't have the nicety of a sniper round, but you must admit its effectiveness.

entries.meaning: Delicacy of character or feeling usually from excessive refinement; fastidiousness
(obsolete) That which is delicate to the taste.
